title: Grow Your Own Grains Part 1: Best Seeding Methods -- Low Tech Video No. 24

tasks.task: Planting grain crops on a small-scale farm

First, the main task here seems to be planting grain crops on a small farm. So the MAINTASK would be planting grain. Then, we need to see the different subtasks involved. The first thing he does is preparation of the soil. He talks about using a tiller, which is a piece of equipment used in farming. But wait, he says he uses a tiller, but he's disking the top just an inch or two, which is called no-till. However, he mentions he hasn't had good luck with no-till because weeds overcompete. So instead, he's tilling a little bit. Hmm, but he also mentions some fields where he just uses no-till with rye, which is working fine. So the soil preparation steps include tilling slightly, which removes weeds but maybe not too deeply. Then he talks about putting horse manure on a certain plot for fertilizing. Wait, horse manure is a natural fertilizer. Do they mention spreading it? The horse manure is used on one field, the barley, while other fields might not have fertilizer. Wait, actually, he says, "If I'm growing other things, I don't. I'll talk about each plant a little bit as we go." Hmm. Wait, the transcript is part of a series, so maybe each part focuses on different aspects—maybe part one is soil prep and planting, part two on harvesting. But in the video transcript, it's part one, so the relevant tasks are preparation, then planting.
Plant oats and barley in rows
subtasks: Set up row markers (white poles every eight inches) so seeder can follow straight rows.
